{{Infobox school |name= Barringer High School |image= Barringer HS Newark jeh.jpg |imagesize= | motto= | motto_translation= | streetaddress = 90 Parker Street | city = [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]] | state = [[New Jersey|NJ]] | district = [[Newark Public Schools]] | zipcode = 07104 | areacode = | principal = Shonda A. Davis[http://www.nps.k12.nj.us/2353209280028440/blank/browse.asp?A=383&BMDRN=2000&BCOB=0&C=57120 Administration], Barringer High School. Accessed October 24, 2011. | viceprincipal = K. Brown
P. Pontoriero
C. Wallace | grades = 9â12 | type = [[state school|Public]] [[high school]] | enrollment = 1,575 (as of 2009-10) | faculty = 108 (on [[full-time equivalent|FTE]] basis) | ratio = 14.58 | language = [[American English|English]] | area = [[Urban area|Urban]] | mascot = | teamname = Blue Bears | colors = Blue and White | established = 1838 | website = [http://www.nps.k12.nj.us/bar School website] }} '''Barringer High School''', formerly '''''Newark High School''''', is a four-year [[comprehensive high school|comprehensive]] [[state school|public]] [[high school]] in [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]], in [[Essex County, New Jersey|Essex County]], [[New Jersey]], United States, operating as part of the [[Newark Public Schools]]. Some consider it to be the [[List of the oldest public high schools in the United States|third oldest public high school]] in the United States. The school has been accredited by the [[Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools]] Commission on Secondary Schools since 1981.[http://www.css-msa.org/search.php?MODE=VIEW%28NJ013%29&org=CSS Barringer High School], [[Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools]] Commission on Secondary Schools. accessed June 28, 2011. As of the 2009-10 school year, the school had an enrollment of 1,575 students and 108 classroom teachers (on an [[full-time equivalent|FTE]] basis), for a [[studentâteacher ratio]] of 14.58.[http://nces.ed.gov/ccd/schoolsearch/school_detail.asp?Search=1&DistrictID=3411340&ID=341134002190 Barringer High School], [[National Center for Education Statistics]]. Accessed September 27, 2011. The school was the 311th-ranked public high school in New Jersey out of 322 schools statewide, in ''[[New Jersey Monthly]]'' magazine's September 2010 cover story on the state's "Top Public High Schools", after being ranked 306th in 2008 out of 316 schools.Staff. [http://njmonthly.com/articles/towns_and_schools/highschoolrankings/top-high-schools-2010.html "2010 Top High Schools"], ''[[New Jersey Monthly]]'', August 16, 2010. Accessed February 12, 2011. The school was ranked 303rd in the magazine's September 2006 issue, which surveyed 316 schools across the state.[http://njmonthly.com/articles/towns_and_schools/highschoolrankings/top-new-jersey-high-schools-by-rank.html "Top New Jersey High Schools 2008: By Rank"], ''[[New Jersey Monthly]]'', September 2008, posted August 7, 2008. Accessed August 19, 2008. == History == In 1838, Nathan Hedges opened a high school in a building on Bank Street. On January 7, 1853, a three-story building was opened at the corner of Washington and Linden and had an enrollment of 498 boys and girls.[http://www.barringeralumni.com/history_of_barringer_high_school.htm History of Barringer High School], Barringer High School. Accessed December 26, 2006. In 1875, Dr. William N. Barringer was hired to succeed George B. Sears as Superintendent of Schools. Dr. Barringer oversaw the construction of a second high school building at a cost of $300,000, which is now the faculty parking lot. Construction started in 1878 and was completed in 1899. In 1907, the name of Newark High School was officially changed to Barringer, in honor of Dr. Barringer. ==Athletics== Barringer High School now competes in the [[Super Essex Conference]], following a reorganization of sports leagues in Northern New Jersey by the [[New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association]].[http://www.njsiaa.org/NJSIAA/10leagueaffiliations.pdf League Memberships â 2011-2012], [[New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association]]. Accessed September 27, 2011. == Notable alumni == ===Arts and Literature=== * [[Jerome Kern]] (1885â1945), composer of musical theatre and popular music.Slonimsky, Nicholas and Laura Kuhn (ed). [http://bakr.alexanderstreet.com/View/673896 Kern, Jerome (David)"]. ''Baker's Biographical Dictionary of Musicians'', Volume 3 (Schirmer Reference, New York, 2001), accessed May 10, 2010 (requires subscription) * [[Amiri Baraka]] (b. 1934), poet and playwright, New Jersey [[Poet Laureate]].[http://www.nathanielturner.com/barakavnewjersey.htm Message from Amiri Baraka, New Jersey and Newark Schools' Poet Laureate], dated July 1, 2003, accessed April 13, 2007. "Now, in an attempt to prevent my appearance at Barringer High School (my alma mater) June 30, to give the Commencement Address, they threatened to picket Barringer and otherwise cause disruption." * [[Hilda Belcher]] (b. 1881), artist known for her [[paintings]], [[watercolors]], and [[Portrait painting|portraits]]. * [[Ted Fio Rito]] (1900-71), singer and songwriter.[http://www.virtualnewarknj.com/memories/newark/bodianted.htm Ted Fiorito: The Newark Son of Italian Immigrants who Became One of Greats of American Music]. Virtual Newark. Accessed December 26, 2006. ===Sports=== [[File:Tippett2008.jpg|thumb|right|160px|Hall of Famer [[Andre Tippett]]]] [[File:MoeBergGoudeycard.jpg| thumb| 160px |[[Moe Berg]]]] * [[Moe Berg]] (1902â72), Major League Baseball player, and spy for the [[CIA]], "the brainiest guy in baseball".Acocella, Nick [http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/classic/bio/news/story?page=Berg_Moe "Moe Berg: Catcher and spy"], [[ESPN.com]], July 29, 2004, accessed April 13, 2007. "Morris Berg was born in a cold-water tenement on East 121st Street in Manhattan on March 2, 1902, to Russian-Jewish immigrant parents â Bernard, a druggist, and Rose.... He later starred at Barringer High School." * [[Robinson CanÃ³]] (b. 1982), baseball player, attended for one year.Araton, Harvey. [http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/sports/baseball/10cano.html "A Fearless Prediction by Yanksâ Cano"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', October 9, 2010. Accessed October 24, 2011. "Cano finished eighth grade and enrolled at Barringer High School, but he failed to make it through his freshman year or to play an inning of high school baseball in New Jersey." * [[Andre Tippett]] (b. 1959), Hall of Fame former linebacker with the [[New England Patriots]].[http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_action=doc&p_docid=0EFD502D5C99C190&p_docnum=2&p_queryname=NaN&p_product=NewsBank&p_theme=aggregated4&p_nbid=J4BH4EDFMTE4NTg0NzQ0OS4yODY4NjU6MTo3OnJhLTE4ODg "THE ULTIMATE NEW JERSEY HIGH SCHOOL YEARBOOK: T-Z AND ALSO..."], ''[[The Star-Ledger]]'', June 27, 1999. Accessed August 4, 2007. ===Government=== * [[William J. Brennan]] (b. 1906), Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court.[http://www.brennancenter.org/article.asp?key=375 Resolution Adopted by the Bar of the Supreme Court of the United States to Record Our Deep Respect and Affection for Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.], accessed December 26, 2006. "The Justice graduated from Barringer High School in 1924." * [[Donald M. Payne]] (b. 1934), Member, [[United States House of Representatives]] from [[New Jersey's 10th congressional district]]; Graduated in 1952.[http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=P000149 Donald Milford Payne, Jr.], ''[[Biographical Directory of the United States Congress]]''. Accessed June 8, 2007. * [[Peter W. Rodino]] (1909â2005), Member, [[United States House of Representatives]] from [[New Jersey's 10th congressional district]].[http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=R000374 Peter Wallace Rodino, Jr.], ''[[Biographical Directory of the United States Congress]]''. Accessed December 26, 2006. * [[Norman Schwarzkopf, Sr.]], (1895â1958), first superintendent of the [[New Jersey State Police]] and father of General "Stormin' Norman" [[Norman Schwarzkopf, Jr.]] * [[George M. Wallhauser]] (1900â93), Member, [[United States House of Representatives]] from [[New Jersey's 12th congressional district]]; graduated in 1918.[http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=W000089 George Marvin Wallhauser], ''[[Biographical Directory of the United States Congress]]''. Accessed June 8, 2007. ===Education=== * [[Steve Adubato, Sr.]] (b. 1932), Founder, [[Robert Treat Academy Charter School]]; graduated in 1949.Local Talk News Editor [http://www.localtalknews.com/newark/community/323-stephen-adubato-to-be-awarded-honorary-degree-from-kean-university "Stephen N. Adubato to be awarded honorary degree from Kean University"], LocalTalkNews.com, May 7, 2010.
